awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Biomimetic Entropic Patterning (BEP) of Nanobiosensors
awd_abstract_narration:
This collaborative research project involves developing sensors for point-of-need testing in food and agricultural applications that can detect regulated pesticides and/or pathogenic bacteria in food or water.  Sensors are being developed using computer algorithms to generate patterns of materials on surfaces. The process is reproducible and does not require the use of expensive equipment or significant training, ensuring the widespread availability of the technique. The research project also encourages students from underrepresented groups to pursue research and graduate school via a series of hands-on teaching activities, undergraduate summer research projects, and informal learning activities in the community. In addition, non-expert audiences are exposed to the underlying science and technology of mobile phone-based biosensors as well as the concepts of biomimicry and fractal mathematics. Finally, the sensor platform developed during this research project has many potential applications, including energy storage, biomedical devices, and solar cells. 

The goal of this research is to develop a new process for patterning micro/nanostructures in biosensing. A new biomimetic entropic patterning technique is proposed to improve signal transduction and durability, particularly under challenging field conditions. The hypothesis is that two-dimensional patterning of nanomaterials leads to optimization of entropy associated with signal transduction. This optimization improves durability, sensitivity, limit of detection, and accuracy of impedimetric and surface plasmon resonance biosensors. The hypothesis has been developed based on the researchers? preliminary exploratory analysis of over 30 patterns for electrochemical sensing, including scale free and non scale-free patterns. For the first time, a correlation between the entropy of patterned nanomaterials and signal transduction is established by testing electrochemical and plasmonic sensors that contain various patterned nanomaterials. The entropy of the pattern is tuned by an in silico two-dimensional model, and techniques such as laser scribing or nanolithography are used to pattern nanomaterials on the sensor surface. This research project will create a multipurpose sensor platform for point of need sensing using mobile phone-based acquisition systems with applications in the areas of ecosystem health and food safety biosensing. To demonstrate the broad applicability of the patterning principle, multiple fabrication techniques are used (laser inscribed graphene, inkjet printing, nanoimprint lithography), and the protocol will be tested by multiple sensor labs with varying skills and equipment through a formal secondary validation process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The rapid detection of bacteria, virus, or chemicals in the environment and in food will help reduce the incidences of foodborne disease outbreaks, reduce transmission of COVID, and help prevent pesticide contamination of food or water. Biosensors are sensors that integrate a biological component to detect these unwanted biological and chemical entities. Biosensors can be fabricated to be low cost, easy-to-use, and rapid in their detection. Here, we explored several fabrication methods to develop biosensors but focused on the patterning of the sensing structure with applications that span multiple domains.    

Biomimetic Entropic Patterning Nanobiosensors use pattering of electrochemical and plasmonic sensor materials that are inspired by the way biological systems sense their environment. Here, we developed a variety of sensors with unique patterning using low cost electrode fabrication methods including laser inscribed graphene, inkjet printing, photolithography, and imprint lithography. These were screened using a custom designed portfolio analyses tool to characterize the performance based on pattern entropy. From these analyses, we selected a subset of 31 promising patterns that showed enhanced sensor performance using laser inscribed graphene.  Tests were performed with a variety of patterning for detection of water condensation as a method for detecting conditions for fungal and bacteria contamination in food as a result of high humidity. Similar metalized electrodes (non-patterned) were bio-functionalized with proteins to detect pesticides using a chemosensor from ants, food contamination (E. coli and Listeria). As an example, modifications with alginate-platinum thiomers and chitosan-platinum brushes detected Listeria by selectively binding to L. monocytogenes even in complex food matrices.These sensors were able to detect low quantities of contaminants in a few minutes at low cost. The transition to use BEPs with these modifications is being explored. A reusability assessment on the BEPs showed that this is highly pattern and modification dependent but many of these can be used repeatably, over six times, in a few of the applications tested. This study has resulted in fundamental knowledge about the effect of unique patterning on nanosensor signal transduction through sensing inspired by life. 

Outreach efforts include a suite of user manuals for fabrication of sensors, a curriculum manual for K-12 teachers, a demonstration at the Cade Science Museum (Gainesville, FL), a variety of infographics and manuals that teach concepts in sensing and biosensors, tours and demos for both undergraduate and graduate students on sensor technologies.

This project has provided engineering training to five graduate students (two from underrepresented groups), eight undergraduates (including 3 female engineering students and two underrepresented groups), and a high school intern (female). These students presented at national and regional professional conferences.  Three of the graduate students completed their degrees and are now pursuing careers in science and engineering. Four of the undergraduates pursued higher level education with others still completing their degree. Several awards for presentations on this project were obtained by students.     

 


Last Modified: 12/23/2022
Modified by: Melanie J Correll

Image
  • Sensors patterned in unique ways show variable responses to treatments.
    Uchechukwu Ilodibe; E. McLamore; M. Correll
    Creative Commons
    Melanie J Correll
    Sensors Inspired By Life
